working_definition: Deafness is a hearing impairment so severe that the student is impaired in processing linguistic information through hearing, with or without amplification, and it adversely affects educational performance.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Profound Hearing Loss
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A complete or near-complete loss of hearing that affects the ability to understand speech even with hearing aids.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A permanent hearing loss resulting from damage to the inner ear or the auditory nerve.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Conductive Hearing Loss
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: Hearing loss caused by problems in the outer or middle ear, which may be temporary or treatable.

other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.name: Hard of Hearing
other_names_or_examples_with_definitions.definition: A term often used for individuals who have some residual hearing and may benefit from hearing aids or other amplification devices.

common_presentations: Limited access to spoken classroom instruction
Needs visual supports for understanding lessons
May miss incidental learning from auditory cues
Relies on sign language or captioning for communication
May require amplification devices (e.g., hearing aids, FM systems)
May have reduced social interaction with hearing peers
Requires environmental modifications to reduce background noise

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of sign language interpreter
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Provides real-time access to spoken instruction
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Limited access to spoken classroom instruction
accommodations_modifications.example: Interpreter translates the teacher’s speech into sign language during class

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of real-time captioning (CART)
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Enables access to spoken content via written transcription
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Relies on sign language or captioning for communication
accommodations_modifications.example: Student views live captions on a tablet during lectures

accommodations_modifications.name: Preferential seating
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves ability to see the speaker and visual aids
accommodations_modifications.example: Student sits in the front row to watch the teacher and interpreter

accommodations_modifications.name: Provide written or visual instructions
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Needs visual supports for understanding lessons
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher provides step-by-step handouts along with oral instructions

accommodations_modifications.name: Use of FM or soundfield amplification system
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves signal-to-noise ratio for students with residual hearing
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: May require amplification devices (e.g., hearing aids, FM systems)
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher wears a microphone that transmits directly to student’s receiver

accommodations_modifications.name: Pre-teaching of vocabulary and concepts
accommodations_modifications.example: Teacher introduces new science terms in advance using visuals

accommodations_modifications.name: Small group or 1:1 instruction
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Allows for repetition, clarification, and individualized support
accommodations_modifications.example: Student reviews math concepts in a small group setting

accommodations_modifications.name: Speech-to-text note-taking tools
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Captures spoken information for later review
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: May miss incidental learning from auditory cues
accommodations_modifications.example: Student uses an app that transcribes lessons into written notes

accommodations_modifications.name: Teach peers basic sign language
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: May have reduced social interaction with hearing peers
accommodations_modifications.example: Classmates learn common signs to communicate during group work

accommodations_modifications.name: Reduce background noise in learning spaces
accommodations_modifications.how_it_helps: Improves hearing clarity for students using amplification devices
accommodations_modifications.addresses_presentation: Requires environmental modifications to reduce background noise
accommodations_modifications.example: Classroom has carpeting, soft furniture, and acoustic panels
